pplied at the level of the whole organism. Nei-
ther of Darwin’s black boxes—the origin of life or the origin of vision (or other
complex biochemical systems)—has been accounted for by his theory.
Irreducible Complexity
In The Origin of SpeciesDarwin stated:
If it could be demonstrated that any complex organ existed which could not pos-
sibly have been formed by numerous, successive, slight modifications, my theory
would absolutely break down.
A system  which  meets  Darwin’s  criterion  is  one
